ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  Kelly Aho
Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  Kelly Aho
Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  Kelly Aho
Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  Kelly Aho
Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  Kelly Aho
Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  Kelly Aho
Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  Kelly Aho
Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  Kelly Aho
Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  Kelly Aho

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  As strengths, Kelly was really accessible and patient with students.
Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  Kelly was great! Always accessible and willing to answer questions.

Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  Kelly was helpful when she knew the answer to the question but I wish she had been more proactive about helping us find out info about the class if she didn't know the answer either.
Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  Kelly had a good grasp on many of the subjects we discussed in class and was, for the most part, able to communicate them clearly.
Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  Was not helpful in answering questions.

Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  I think Kelly could have been prepared with more practice problems, primarily in the beginning of the year when we were reviewing basic chemistry concepts. Thank this would've been particularly helpful to set the pace for the rest of the semester. Our conversations were primarily based on the problem sets, or some misconceptions prior to midterms and finals. I think it would been really nice to have more skill building incorporated into the help sessions. Especially having some opportunities to work with the equations are provided in class briefly to be very helpful.
Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  I didn't interact with Kelly at all, but she seemed quite friendly and helpful.

Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  Kelly was great, it would have been nice if she had more office hours. Also perhaps if Gabe gave her more guidance on what things were most important to review for exams, etc.
Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  Kelly was very accessible, and responded to questions promptly. She was very helpful in making clarifications and in helping to review key concepts.
Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  Great prep sessions. However, 'learning it all by heart' is not helpful. It was better when she gave us an insight of how gabe usually asks questions
Instructor: Kelly Sue Aho  She was very helpful in understanding concepts when I brought questions to her in the office hours.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Lectures are very fast-paced and occasionally tangential. It is not always clear whether what is being covered is entirely relevant to the topic at hand.

I really enjoyed all of the different case studies in topics covered in this course. I do think that at times the lecture could be somewhat jumbled, and without titles on most of the slides provided, it was sometimes hard to figure out what the train of thought was when studying. I do think some of the math of mathematical concepts all mentioned were not explained in detail enough that I felt comfortable with the concepts they represented.

It is sometimes hard to follow Gabe's lectures. He jumps around a bit. It would be very helpful if his slides (handouts) were in the order in which they are presented and had appropriate labels and titles. Also when he is lectures he sometimes writes things on the board but other times uses abbreviations or doesn't write them at all.

Gabe is an incredibly passionate instructor although he only showed this openly towards the end of the course. I feel like a good book would have helped to structure my knowledge better, however I really appreciated the white board notes and the step by step approach of instructing.

Gabe is a great teacher. I struggled a bit in class because I didn't have much of a chemistry background, but was able to do background research and end up doing ok. I think it was helpful that he didn't require us to memorize many chemical equations for exams, especially for someone who doesn't have much of a background in chemistry. However, it might be helpful for him to specify a couple equations that we *should* commit to memory, equations that are found regularly throughout other environmental work (the weather equation, for example). A better review before exams would have been helpful as well...maybe something that Kelly or future TF's could hold?

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Clear that the professor cares about and is knowledgable about this subject material
I can see very tangible ways in which this course will benefit my in my future career. The information could have been presented in a more organized manner.

I was glad that we spent so much time on basic water quality parameters. As a result, I feel that I have a strong grasp on this subject. The highlight of the course was the HBEF field trip, which put a lot of the material into perspective and enhanced my understanding of watershed processes, experimentation, chemistry, etc.
The material in this course was so applicable to any environmental scientist. Case studies were helpful and great way to engage students.

I thought the layout of the different topics and course materials were straightforward and easy to use. I also thought that the field trips were an excellent addition and helped to supplement the information learned in class.

The format with heavy emphasis on writing on the board paces the class just right; it allows everyone to keep up without being overwhelmed by powerpoint slides on this technical information. The slides were used to complement and provide graphical support to the information.
Hubbard brook and gabe's personal insights that made chemistry much more approachable. It's also so empowering to know how much you will know after this course.
Enjoyed how applicable it was to the real world and the field trips made my really excited about the material.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The use of one good textbook to provide structure for those without a significant background/for reference with the chemistry would help. Please put titles on all figures/more explanations. Overall we needed more structure/organization.
Delivering the material in a more organized manner.
Perhaps more organization with slides (i.e. titles). It would also be helpful to have access to in-class slides.
More organized slides, slides were often out of order and not labelled. Also would be helpful if problem sets were due well before exam so they could be used as study material.
Teaching style was very unclear and disorganized.

I think finding a better balance between the problem sets and skills they require and what's presented in class would be helpful. Also perhaps working on making the lecture portion a bit more organized, with slide titles.
For the most part, the class was logically organized, but occasionally during lecture there would be double-backs and diversions, which could be a bit confusing.
Lectures

It would be helpful if notes were more well-organized. Also, more specific direction in terms of review of key concepts from general chemistry would be useful for those of us with a weak background in chemistry.
Coherence of instruction

Better review before exams...a lot of information is given in the course, and I tended to way overstudy and get into the nitty gritty details of what Gabe would say in class (and what I wrote down in notes). If you get into all the details of what is covered, I don't think that is a reasonable amount of material to study (it would be too much). Having a study guide would help curb the amount of time invested in studying.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Field trips were relevant and interesting. It was just a lot of time to fit in to an already busy schedule with many other field trips.
Yes.

I only attended the lab section once, and Kelly was there to answer questions, so it was helpful, but it didn't seem to have too much of a relationship to the course lecture, but I think in this case, it wasn't necessary. I don't think it needs to be improved, except a possibly a prepared exam review session (powerpoint, etc).

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Good foundation for future water courses (i.e. watershed cycles and processes, environmental hydrology, etc.)
This course is really relevant to anyone interested in pursuing environmental science, fewer students should be intimidated and try this course.
This course is crucial to my the degree and that biogeochemistry is my topic of study. I thought it was a great introduction to the rest of my time at school.
It provides me with a lot of information about water dynamics and the chemical makeup of water, which I hope to be able to use within my career path, ideally doing some sort of water management.
Since I am focusing on water this was very relevant.
As a student with interests in water quality and related topics, this course will be directly informative in helping me to develop research questions and methodologies for testing them.
Great overview of environmental issues that we are trying to combat. Helps give us encouragement for our research because we are trying to solve the issues that we were studying in the course!

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Relevant to my future studies and career.
See above.
Relevant to my reserach.
I took this course because I wanted a strong foundation in understanding ecological systems to biogeochemistry, specifically water systems.
It looked interesting and pertinent to my studies, and it provided a bit more background in water management and geobiochemical dynamics that I had not had before.
Wanted the background material.
I never liked chemistry but I seemed to need it so I wanted to finally nip it in the bud. Who knew I would actually get out of it liking chemistry?!
Took it because I didn't have a strong background in chemistry and thought this course might help me.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes
Yes - of all my classes this one gives me the most direct, relevant skills to future work.
Yes.
Yes.
Definitely, as a non-chemist I got way more out of this course than I expected.
I do feel that I gained quite a bit of knowledge from this course, and I thought it complemented well with my other course selection for the semester.

Yes. Though the chemistry was a bit daunting at first, it helped provide me with an understanding of what a typical water sample should look like, and what sort of management solutions would be appropriate in different cases.
Ability to think chemically.
Yes, although I could use more information on/experience with field and laboratory methodologies (though I guess that's what aquatic chemistry is for?)
Exceeded my expectations

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take good notes. Create your own organizational strategy to make the material make sense to you
Go to office hours, start the homework early and brush up on college level chemistry before the course begins.
Take advantage of office hours and group study sessions.
Don't be intimidated! If you do the work and take the initiative you can learn so much from this course.

I would be very up front that while day-to-day it's not super intensive, preparing for the assessments is very intensive and requires a lot of pre-planning and focus. Also the problem sets require quite a bit of foresight and time to think over the questions. But overall, the course is an excellent one and you learn a lot. But be prepared to feel a bit overwhelmed at times. If you have very little understanding of general chemistry, you might be experiencing a steeper learning curve.
Brush up on your chemistry, and be sure to stay engaged during class, a lot of information passes by and is gone rapidly.
Review materials as you go. You'll likly need to teach yourself a lot.

Pay attention to the problem sets, as they'll be helpful in preparing for exams. Try to go on as many field trips as you can (more than just the minimum required), especially if you learn well through experiential methods.
If you need chemistry TAKE THIS COURSE. It's a lot of work but absolutely worth it. Also if you take this course ASK QUESTIONS. It will make your experience much more worth your while

Know that it is a lot of valuable and good information, but thankfully not a huge workload. Still learn loads in the course though! Great course overall. Very appropriate for folks in forestry and engineering alike (I am an engineering student in Chemical and Environmental Engineering).
